bill.title: Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 129) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to "Restoring Internet Freedom".

item.text: Sets forth the rule for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 129) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to "Restoring Internet Freedom".
item.name: Introduced in House

latestAction.text: Motion to Discharge Committee filed by Mr. Doyle, Michael F.Petition No: 115-11. (Discharge petition text with signatures.)

item.text: Motion to Discharge Committee filed by Mr. Doyle, Michael F.Petition No: 115-11. (Discharge petition text with signatures.)
Referred to the House Committee on Rules.

On 5/17/2018, a motion was filed to discharge the Committee on Rules from the consideration of H.RES. 873, a resolution providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 129). A discharge petition requires 218 signatures for further action. (Discharge Petition No. 115-11: text with signatures.)

item.title: Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 129) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to "Restoring Internet Freedom".

Providing for consideration of the joint resolution (H.J. Res. 129) providing for congressional disapproval under chapter 8 of title 5, United States Code, of the rule submitted by the Federal Communications Commission relating to "Restoring Internet Freedom".

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
